title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.12.26 | 05-09-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from the 26th verse of the 12th chapter of the 1st canto of Shri Madbhagavati.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and an introduction to the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam that will be discussed.

segments.key_quote: The meaning of this verse is this child will be the father of kings who will be like sages for world peace and for the sake of religion.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the meaning of the verse, highlighting the qualities of a king who is like a sage, promoting world peace and religion.

segments.key_quote: The wisest man in the world is a devotee of the Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that the wisest person is a devotee of the Lord and discusses the lineage of wise kings in Maharaja Yudhishthira's family.

segments.key_quote: As will be clear in the chapters ahead, the later chapters of this canto, Maharaja Pariksit wanted to kill the personified kali who was attempting to kill a cow, the emblem of peace and religion.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Pariksit Maharaj and his intolerance towards Kali Purusha's attempt to kill a cow.

segments.key_quote: The symptoms of kali are wine, women, gambling and slaughterhouses.
segments.summary: The speaker describes the symptoms of Kali Yuga and contrasts them with the four pillars of Dharma in Satya Yuga, explaining how irreligion destroys these pillars.

segments.key_quote: With the progression of the age of Kali people are becoming very proud they are becoming attached to women and they are attached to intoxication
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on how pride, lust, and intoxication are rampant in Kali Yuga, leading to corruption and moral degradation.

segments.key_quote: People can be cured of these evils by advocating the principles of Brahmanical culture or the principles of austerity, cleanliness, mercy and truthfulness
segments.summary: The speaker suggests that the solution to these problems lies in promoting Brahmanical culture and the principles of austerity, cleanliness, mercy, and truthfulness.

segments.key_quote: The solution to this problem is to create a new society... and educate them in god consciousness.
segments.summary: The speaker criticizes modern civilization for creating poverty and irreligion, advocating for a new society based on God consciousness.

segments.key_quote: We have to defeat Kali by spreading Sankirtana, the chanting of the holy name of God. So that is the only solution.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing the importance of Sankirtana and following the example of Maharaj Pariksit to maintain peace and morality, ending the lecture with Hare Krishna.
